bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Bert W. Caldwell, April 24, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] believes that human “carriers” of yellow fever, without symptoms, do not exist. He feels that Caldwell's case must involve either a human with undiagnosed yellow fever or an erroneous diagnosis of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Bert W. Caldwell, April 24, 1922
div1.opener:
Connor
I. H. B.
Caldwell
Copy sent Connor
Please return to
H. R. Carter
2121 California street N. W
Washington D. C.
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
April 24, 1922.
Dear Doctor Caldwell:
div1.p: I will answer your questions categorically.

First I take your definition of carriers: “One infective to
Stegomyia mosquitoes.”

The existence of carriers without symptoms--or continuing as
such after the attack of yellow fever has recovered--I count exceed-
ingly improbable. There is no evidence therefor whatever; except analogy

If, however, one simply means a man with an infection so slight
or so ill defined as to make diagnosis very difficult--or indeed in
individual cases impossible--such carriers are of common occurrence.
I have never seen an epidemic in which there were not cases recognized
as such by the conditions under which they occurred, which had other-
wise been impossible of diagnosis. I would not consider these carriers,
however, in the ordinary implsignication of the word--merely light cases
of yellow fever.

I know of no latent infection of yellow fever incapable of in-
fecting mosquitoes--or indeed of any latent infection of yellow fever
at all: Nor is there any evidence for it.

1/ To your 1st. question: In my opinion there is substantial
reason for believing that yellow fever carriers do not exist and none
none
2.
whatever for believing that they do.

2/ My experience has not at any time suggested that carriers
have been a factor in the epidemiology of yellow fever, on the contrary
thea large number of people from places infected with yellow fever have been
introduced into the infectable part of the U. S. without any known in-
fection therefrom. See the enclosed article.

3/ I have known of patients having had yellow fever a second time--
not oftener, however, than the same has been true of smallpox--the second
attack coming after an interval of some years and during an epidemic was
quite certainly a new infection.

I took up this matter (“The Immunity of Yellow Fever”) some years ago.
I am sending you a Spanish translation of the paper I wrote at that time,
published in the Liverpool Journal, Annals of Tropical Medicine and Para-
sitology. I have not read it over--I mean the translation--but if there
are errors in it I judge there are not enough of them to vitiate the ar-
gument. Of necessity, since the proposition is a negative one: that
secondary attacks do not occur (or no more often than with other immunizing
infections) the argument therefor must necessarily be negative and, as
negative evidence is convincing in proportion to its mass, it may be there
is not a sufficient mass of it presented. The fact presented is that
with over 30,000--probably 50,000 or 60,000-people “immune to yellow fever
by previous attack or ten years residence in an infected focus” came from
Havana into the infectable part of the U. S. (Tampa and Key West) without
communicating any infection to the Stegomyiae of these last two places,
while among 450 people not so immune, 13 cases of yellow fever developed
at the Quarantine Station.

It would seem to me that this shows that a previous attack gives a
fairly sufficient protection against subsequent ones.

For carriers, in addition to the above 30,000 to 60,000--who mightshould also
have had some carriers among them if there be any such things--sharply over 100,000 people who had been
been
3.
exposed to yellow fever entered the U. S. at Southern ports during the summer season without con-
veying any infection to Stegomyiae.

The Commission of the Pasteur Institute--Marchoux and others--have
promulgated the idea that yellow fever practically never disappears from
there are so many erroneous statements in the Report of
from a focus one infected if the Stegomyiae continue in sufficient num-
this Commission that one is surprised at seeing how absolutely it is ac-
ber and active “being kept up by recurrent attacks among the indigene”
cepted as authoritative in Latin America. They are wrong in their statement
They believe that the immunity given by an attack of yellow fever is not
that infected stegomyiae do not in nature feed in the day time. They are
only not permanent, but ephemeral and that recurrent attacks are common and
recur many times in the same man. They present no evidence therefor--simply
make this assertion. It was to meet this--that I consider mistaken view--
that the article I send you was written. I think it (my view) is generally accepted
by tropical sanitarians.

For the second part: I wrote in 1917 an article on the Spontaneous
Elimination of Yellow Fever by Failure of the Human Host. I judge you
have seen that.

Your own experience--certainly the experience of many of the physi-
cians in Mexico--will show that yellow fever does not continue indefinitely
in small or moderate sized places, even if no Stegomyia work is done. It
does not become latent--it dies out--as completely as measles or whooping-
cough does.

In effect there are so many erroneous statements in the Report of
this Commission that one is surprised at seeing how absolutely it is ac-
cepted as authoritative in Latin America. They are wrong in their statement
that infected Stegomyiae do not in nature feed in the day time. They are
wrong in the lower limit of temperature they set for Stegomyia feeding and
flight. Fernando Lopez of Mexico City has shown that, as well as recent obser-
vations in Peru. It is quite probablequite certain that they are wrong in claiming con-
veyance by the progeny of the infected mosquito, though I cannot say this
is absolutely proven against them. The trouble was that they assumed a theory
theory
theory
4.
and almost compelled their observations to sustain it.

There are four conceivable explanations of the occurrence of your case
of March 20th.

1/ That a mosquito may have retained its infection from the previous
September. I count this extremely improbable--so much so that I would re-
ject it altogether.

2/ That the infection was from a mosquito infected on account of be-
ing the progeny of one infected in September. It is so highly improbable--
though not maybe impossible- that this method of conveyance takes place
that I feel also like throwing it into the discard.

3/ That other cases occurred on the plantation subsequent, and well
subsequent, to September. No one can always recognize light cases of yel-
low fever, especially in children, and there might have been several such,
between September and March. This is not at all improbable.

4/ The case of March 20th. may not have been yellow fever. There
are a number of the so-called infectuous jaundices caused by spirochetes,
which it is very difficult to differentiate from yellow fever. I saw five
such cases under conditions which excluded yellow fever and I confess had
it been during an epidemic of that disease I would unquestionably have
listed them with yellow fever. Weil's Disease (Leptospira ictero-haemmo-
rhagica) is one of these, and the five I saw were this disease. Such
diseases occur from time to time in various places not confined to the
Tropics: Quebec: Dundee, Scotland: two of mine were at Mound City, Illinois
in March; and it is no discredit to anyone to mistake such cases for yellow
fever.

If your case was yellow fever, the presumption is you should e'er this
have had other cases as the diagnosis was probably not made before he had a
chance to feed a certain number of Stegomyiae and I would like much to hear
hear
the further outcome, of the matter.

Give my best respects to Mrs. Caldwell and young Henry, whom I have
never had the pleasure of seeing.
With best wishes to yourself,

closer.seg:
P. S. You can keep the Spanish translation as long as you want--say a month
or two months, but I would be glad to have it again, as I have no reprints
of it.
